Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2008 08:36PM Keryl wrote: Yes, I have my 2nd round of AC tomorrow. I am on every two weeks for 8 weeks, then taxol every week of 12 weeks. My side effects have basically been exhaustion, a bit of a tummy in the afternoons and some sleep deprevation. My hair is in place, but my scalp itches at times -- am I imagiing that? hoping tomorrow goes ok. I have some lydocane cream for my port, but not sure what to do with it ???? Take care all.
Posts.Title: AC every 2 weeks..? susan13 Keryl

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 08:38PM Keryl wrote: Hi there. I was DX in May 08 with DCIS - Drs. recommended lumpectomy and radiation. I am 49. It was found on a routine mammogram. After the lumpectomy pathology was more complicated than anticipated and I have moved on to Masectomy, and node removal based on those details. I did go ahead with BRCA genetic testing before making the decision to only remove one breast as my BRCA was negative. I too have a 20 year old daughter and really wanted to know about BRCA as my mom had breast cancer too, but no other female relatives even exist that I know of so no more than that to go on....  Based on your info., you might want to definintely consider BRCA testing. I am explaining this to emphsize that things do change along the way as more testing is done and more pathology is done. What I thought was straight forward, turned to be more complicated. While I will get through this, I could not count on initial blush and plans can change with more information, so just know that and be open.  I ended up removing only one breast as there was nothing going on with the healthy breast and I had the BCRA negative. I will be on close watch there though! On a good note, I had immediate reconstruction on my masectomy side in July and it went very well. I am very pleased with my my new breast and I am not even done yet!!   While the most impt. thing is prognosis and health, at least my breast is moving in the right direction!    I wish you the best. We will get through this. Would definitely go for the genetic test and counseling as with a family history, it may tell you a lot and support the decision you make. take care.

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 05:20PM Keryl wrote: Hi all - just had my left mast. on tuesday 7/29; I agree with those that have reported the mast surgery is not easy, but not that terrible (and I am a wimp) the first few days are groggy and then you will hopefully easily pull out of it. My fear now is the SNB results; hopefully, clear. Want to move on to reconstruction, and health outlook. ITCHY...TOTALLY ITCHY. I do think the reconstruction options are confusing....I had to stop reading on sites about this and put my ultimate cards with my Dr. as there is so much conflicting info. out there, it made me so anxious. I do have great confidence in my medical team.  A side note, both my parents passed away last fall and I have few blood relatives. My kids have been great though they are just teens. Anyone out there felt alone, lonely, sad.... at age 49 still longing for my mommy....what is that about?
Posts.Title: masectomy - seems like this sucks rseaw22 Mandy1313

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2008 09:52AM Keryl wrote: I just got the call from surgeon yesterday that my path came back unexpectedly with IDC and node involvement. I meet with oncologist tomorrow. what started out as simple DCIS has become much more than that. I had left masectomy on 7/29, still have drain in (ugh) and have reconstruction with expander underway....now what? more aux. node dissection and expect I'll have chemo and other stuff to consider. My BRCA came back negative, but I still have cancer in family, so not sure that is enough reassurance. Small part of me wishes I had gone bi-lateral. I really feel like I am losing it about all this...I am very emotional and can't get my head around it. My daughter is being really sweet, but I want to appear strong for her, but I dont feel so strong right now. I got mad last night and hid one of my pictures of my parents because I miss them so much.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 11:51AM Keryl wrote: I finished rads 3/27. I was great through it all - not even that fatigued. I had one red/raw senstive spot on my clavicle until friday. On friday 3/27 I had two sessions - to finish up. one at 9am ; the other at 4pm; on Sunday my arm, pit, and chest took a turn. Very, very tight, very, very swollen. I was miserale for about 48 hours. Took advil and did the lymph massage that my PT advised to get the swelling down. I must say, it seemed to work, despite the skeptic in me. This week I started swimming again and though tight at first, the xercise really helps loosen it up. my recon. breast is till harder than before, but we'll see if it relaxes..... Took my first tamoxifen daily this week....so I am off and running to next phase....hair is short grey stuble. I do have a few eyebrows coming in........best of all, I am feeling a bit brighter.  I hope you are all doing well. Hang in there!

I will have a lift and symmetry surgery on the healthy side, hopefully at the same time. Unless of course any check up  between now and then looks suspicious, then that second breast is outta there. Sometimes I wish I had the bilateral, but here I am...

Posts.Title: Is this Lymphedema? JoniB Keryl

Posts.Content: May 16, 2009 10:21AM Keryl wrote: My situation sounds similar to others, most similar to Pringles1. I had implants and a routine mammo identified microcalcifications. (no lump)  I was put on watch, but by the time they "changed" I needed an excisional biopsy which identified DCIS only. From there I had a MRI which indicated some additional suspicious areas, hence, I immediately opted for a masectomy and immediate reconstruction on my left side. The pathology came back with DCIS and IDC and 4 positive nodes. This was not what the MD expected based on the initial mammo & excisional biopsy, but it was there! and only finally determined by the more major action & pathology. My advice - act early and act aggressively. If I had not opted for the masectomy, I am not sure I would have found all of this as quickly....and even so, it was also in my nodes so that was very upsetting; resulting in chemo and radiation. I just had my one year mammo on my "good" side; they did find some microcalcifications "within normal range" - I am 50 years old. I am now thinking about whether I should have/or should have a prophmasectomy on the right.,  My oncologist is not in favor of it and feels it is not nescessary to remove healthy tissue - BUT based on how quickly things progressed for me, I am re-thinking AND definitely would encourage you to at a minimum, get an extensive biopsy and insure you have as much information about your Dx. Please, please request and/or insist on an excisional biopsy. In my experience, the augmentation had no impact on all of this and MD said so, as well. The only thing that came up was that there are only specific doctors that are best with needle biopsies when implants present. I would go for excisional if microcalcs since it takes a slice of tissue Hope this helps.

Posts.Title: Anyone have implants, then get DCIS Keryl LUVmy2girlZ

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 01:24AM Keryl wrote: I had the BRCA testing also and was negative. My dr. had me go for counseling also,as I do have some other cancer in my family on both sides (mother and father) I was told that about 5-10% of all breast cancers have a hereditary component; but another 15% are termed "familial" meaning that there is likley a genetic susceptibility within the family.which cannot be specifically identified. Familial breast cancer also involves the presence of environmental contributions or triggers. The counselor will talk to you about your family health history on both sides of your family to see if they think there might be some familial genetic suceptibility based on that info. (though it is hard to quanitfy) I have a 20 year old daughter so I went to counseling to find out more about what she should do ; test 10 years earlier than my onset etc.  It also reinforces frequent testing and monitoring of your situation going forward. I did not have a bilateral,  but unilateral, and this somewhat has influenced me to think about it should anything look even slightly suspicious.  Not sure what your situation is, but that was my experience with the counseling.  The counselor wrote a letter that recapped our discussion and sent it to me and to the oncologist, so on my next appt. will discuss again with him.  He thinks my greatest risk is reoccurance from the first side, not so much to worry the second side. Either way, I worry about both!  I hope it is helpful to you. I am of the opinion that more information is better ....to a point,  and I think the discussion I had with the genetic counselor was a good one.

Is that what you refer to as the full test vs. the founders test? I have not heard the founders terminlology in my materials or from the genetic counselor, but sounds like I had the full test.  Thanks.

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 11:38PM Keryl wrote: I am having nipple sparing surgery next month with masectomy on the left side. I will have expander under muscle (saline implant that they enlarge over time ) that I may or may not xchange for silicone once at the desired size/fit.   Dr. said my nipple placement may not be perfect afterwards and I can either leave it or have a lift on either side. I am pleased I have the option of nipple sparing as that was the component most distressing to me. Funny, I have never really liked my nipple, but then in this situation, it is a whole new world. The decision on sparing the nipple should not just be aethetic, but with oncology  considerations.
Posts.Title: mastectomy nipple vonnie dfleaman

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2009 11:22PM Keryl wrote: Hi Lynnea. Both my parents a passed in 2007. It was a huge blow. My Mom had been ill with a chronic condition for over 10 years, then my Dad plummeted in her later years, and then quickly thereafter. I spent so much time caring for them, working fulltime,  navigating their issues from health & medical to health benefits to housing to personal belongings to safety to financial to emotional to anger to then to depression  - my parents referred to my outside assistance as the "jailor" or being put in the "slammer" -- I used to cry (sob) so hard because I was doing the best I could.   While I know it is costly, I tried the best I could for good care and peace of mind. It was worth it --even though I dont think they would be satisfied because they did not live to infinity and beyond....... (ok , but they were age 76 and aged 81)  I have a lot of issues about this, but was jolted into reality with my own diagnosis in May '08. While I am not a blamer, I dont think all of that helped. I miss my parents dearly and sometimes long for their words and their hugs. (I am 50!) I still can hear my Mother's voice during consoling moments and in quite moments I have to reconcile my situation with them. My best friend (who is also a MD) said do what you need to do, do not have regrets......take good care of yourself. I am glad your mammo was benign, but even so, we are still vulnerable - if you are in this situation, take care, get help, eat and exercise well. Remember, you can only do the best you can and even then, it may not be enough.....take care.
Posts.Title: Are you a Caregiver for a parent? lynnea lynnea
